Name: TV Dinner
Description:
TV Dinner opened in August 1981 at the former site of the Aquarius Lounge strip club on Peachtree. Founders Finnian Jones and Rosa Phillips initially envisioned the space as a "video club" but also hosted music shows and ran a restaurant in the space. TV Dinner was among the first of The American Music Show’s many associations with Atlanta performance and nightlife venues. The show taped episodes here on election night 1981 and the subsequent runoff election. TV Dinner regularly screened TAMS episodes in their space – likely the earliest public screenings of the show outside broadcast TV. Longtime TAMS regulars The Now Explosion held their second live show here. The venue once hosted poet Allen Ginsberg for a spontaneously organized reading (seen in the linked video). [See: Thrasher, Glen. "The Once and Future Club, T.V.D." The Signal (Georgia State University), September 28, 1982; and Facebook page for TV Dinner, https://www.facebook.com/TV-Dinner-128124327223093/]

Andy Ditzler

Media:

Name: 688 Club
Description:
From 1980 to 1986, the legendary 688 Club (named for its address on Spring St and 3rd) hosted hundreds of punk and alternative band performances by the likes of R.E.M., the Ramones, and the Replacements. The American Music Show had a presence here as well. In this video, RuPaul and the U-Hauls perform at 688 with Wee Wee Pole (Robert Burke Warren on bass, Todd Butler on guitar).

Andy Ditzler
Media 1 title:
RuPaul & Wee Wee Pole at 688 in 1983 doing "Funky for a Honky" and "Body Heat"

RuPaul & Wee Wee Pole at 688 in 1983 doing "Funky for a Honky" and "Body Heat"
Media: RuPaul & Wee Wee Pole at 688 in 1983 doing "Funky for a Honky" and "Body Heat"

Name: Celebrity Club
Description:
The Celebrity Club was a frequent site of TAMS-associated live performances (such as the video seen here with drag queens Lahoma van Zandt and Judy LaGrange). Larry Tee of the Now Explosion and TAMS regular Tom Zarrilli worked there. The building now houses the Atlanta Eagle.

Andy Ditzler
Location: 306 Ponce De Leon Ave NE, Atlanta, GA 30308
Media 1 title: Lahoma van Zandt's Tribute to Judy LaGrange at the Celebrity Club in Atlanta in 1986
Media: Lahoma van Zandt's Tribute to Judy LaGrange at the Celebrity Club in Atlanta in 1986

Name: Frances Hotel
Description:
Originally opened in 1898 as the Farlinger Building, the once chic Frances Hotel had declined considerably by the late 1980s. At this time there were plans to renovate the building to house a new version of The Celebrity Club. In this video Stephen Stubbs, known by his DJ name House Fairy, leads TAMS co-founder Dick Richards on a tour of the hotel interior during renovation. The project fell apart and the building was razed not long after.

Andy Ditzler
Location: 343 Peachtree St (Peachtree St and Ivy St [now Peachtree Center Ave])
Media 1 title: House Fairy tours prospective Celebrity Club location
Media: House Fairy tours prospective Celebrity Club location

Name: Shady Rest Hotel (now Highland Inn)
Description:
Later remodeled and now known as the Highland Inn, the Shady Rest Hotel housed renters in cheap rooms. In this April 1988 video, Stephen Stubbs (a/k/a House Fairy) takes drag queens Judy LaGrange and Lahoma van Zandt on a tour of the inside, including his $85-a-week room. From the scary-looking ceiling to the bathroom and shower (“That’s really slimy down there and when I take a shower, the water rises up to my calves”), the camera spares us nothing.

Andy Ditzler
Location: 644 North Highland Avenue Northeast, Atlanta, GA 30306
Media 1 title: Drag Queens Tour the Shady Rest Hotel in Atlanta
Media: Drag Queens Tour the Shady Rest Hotel in Atlanta

Name: Club Rio
Description:
One of Atlanta’s most celebrated 1980s nightlife spots, Club Rio hosted the likes of David Bowie. It was managed by Michael Krohngold who, with partner Louis Spetrini, later opened Colorbox in Virginia Highland and Velvet downtown. All three clubs hosted numerous performances by American Music Show regulars and the associated Funtone record label. In this video, the beloved Singing Peek Sisters arrive at Club Rio to open for Funtone recording artists Cocktail Girlz.

Andy Ditzler
Media 1 title: The Singing Peek Sisters arrive at the Cocktail Girlz Record Release Party at Club Rio
Media:
The Singing Peek Sisters arrive at the Cocktail Girlz Record Release Party at Club Rio

The Singing Peek Sisters Official Show-Starter Video

Media 2: The Singing Peek Sisters Official Show-Starter Video

Name: RuPaul's second midtown apartment
Description:
RuPaul lived in this converted apartment house on 11th and Juniper St in the mid-1980s, all the while appearing regularly on The American Music Show, go-go dancing at the Weekends club, appearing in action movies filmed by Wayne Hollowell and Jon Witherspoon, developing his Starbooty character, and making his first records (and continuing his inroads into the New York City scene). His friends Trade (a TAMS semi-regular) and Spicey (who appeared in Hollowell’s Mahagony II) lived downstairs.

Andy Ditzler
Location: 1035 Juniper St NE (11th St and Juniper St)

Name: 10th and Peachtree (Much Ado About Midtown festival)
Description:
This corner hosted a 1982 Now Explosion performance for the Much Ado About Midtown festival, later broadcast on The American Music Show. Atlanta legend Opal Foxx, a/k/a Benjamin of the band Smoke, is seen here as a guest performer, interacting with the crowd as First Lady Nancy Reagan. The Now Explosion appeared frequently on The American Music Show from its beginnings.

Andy Ditzler
Media 1 title: Now Explosion Live with Opal Foxx as Nancy Reagan at Much Ado About Midtown Festival 1982
Media: Now Explosion Live with Opal Foxx as Nancy Reagan at Much Ado About Midtown Festival 1982

Name: WRFG
Description:
The American Music Show’s first iteration was in the mid-1970s as a radio show, co-hosted by founders James Bond and Dick Richards on the long-running independent FM station WRFG. The show featured music and character-based parody skits of the kind later refined on the TV show. In one notorious broadcast, Bond (at the time a member of Atlanta’s City Council) locked himself in the control room and repeatedly played the then-current hit “How Long” by Ace. The song’s refrain, “How long has this been going on?,” looped ceaselessly, to many complaints.

Andy Ditzler

Name: Metronome
Description:
This long-defunct 80s record store hosted the world famous “battle of the hair” between RuPaul and New York club performer John Sex (1956-1990). This video was taped for the American Music Show by Dick Richards, and features longtime performers Molli Worthington (as singing star/investigative journalist Wanda Peek) and Paul Burke (as announcer Ralph Bailey).

Andy Ditzler
Media: Battle of the Hair

Name: Colorbox
Description:
Located near the corner of Virginia and Highland Avenues, Colorbox was the first club opened by Club Rio manager Michael Krohngold and Louis Spetrini. The American Music Show presented live shows here, and were frequent visitors. This video by Nelson Sullivan is a valuable document of the relatively short-lived venue. In the first half we see RuPaul at home preparing for the show, with show co-founder Dick Richards, cast members Molli Worthington and Rosser Shymanski, and friends. The video’s second half extensively documents Colorbox’s back entrance, tiny dressing room, and the stage and audience area during RuPaul’s performance. Sullivan’s camerawork, while always deft, is especially good here.

Andy Ditzler
Media 1 title: Taking RuPaul to the Colorbox in Atlanta to do a show in 1989
Media: Taking RuPaul to the Colorbox in Atlanta to do a show in 1989

Name: Weekends
Description:
Weekends is a fondly remembered 80s midtown night spot. Around the time of releasing his first Funtone album Sex Freak, RuPaul earned money as a go-go dancer at this bar. The dance floor was lit from below a la Saturday Night Fever. Typically for Nelson Sullivan’s club videos, this clip of Weekends documents both an event in the main space (RuPaul’s go-go dancing near the crowded dance floor) and its offstage component (hanging out with friends in the dressing room, including TAMS co-founder Dick Richards and Larry Tee of the Now Explosion).

Andy Ditzler
Media 1 title: RuPaul - Professional Go-Go Dancer at Weekends Atlanta in the Mid-1980s
Media:
RuPaul - Professional Go-Go Dancer at Weekends Atlanta in the Mid-1980s

RuPaul's Nightclub Act with Trade & Spicey at Weekends Atlanta in 1986
Media 2 title: RuPaul's Nightclub Act with Trade & Spicey at Weekends Atlanta in 1986
Media 2: RuPaul's Nightclub Act with Trade & Spicey at Weekends Atlanta in 1986

Name: Velvet
Description:
Velvet was one of the most important venues to The American Music Show. It was the second club opened by Michael Krohngold and Louis Spetrini (after Colorbox and before the long-running Tongue and Groove). TAMS presented live shows here nearly once a week, in the upstairs VIP lounge space known as Popcorn – all while Dick Richards continued to release records on Funtone and create the weekly cable TV show. In this video TAMS stalwart Paul Burke (as announcer Ralph Bailey) introduces the wild and beloved poet and performer Deacon Lunchbox.

Andy Ditzler
Media 1 title: Deacon Lunchbox "Several Poems" at Club Velvet Atlanta
Media: Deacon Lunchbox "Several Poems" at Club Velvet Atlanta

Name: The Nitery
Description:
A precursor to the Celebrity Club, the Nitery was an important early venue for TAMS-related live shows. Regular TAMS cast member and Atlanta concert booker Tom Zarrilli worked here prior to a stint at the later club. In the first video linked here, RuPaul is interviewed backstage at the Nitery by James Bond as he prepares to perform for the first time with his new band Wee Wee Pole (Robert Burke Warren on bass, Todd Butler on guitar), and we see some of the performance and its aftermath as well. In the second video, Zarrilli performs the song “Destroy Midtown” with the band Attack and Decay at the Nitery’s last show, in protest of the club’s closing due to gentrification. The Nitery building on Ponce has housed Eats restaurant since 1993.

Andy Ditzler
Media 1 title: RuPaul debuts his Wee Wee Pole band at The Nitery in Atlanta
Media:

Name: Piedmont Park cruising trails
Description:
In this classic 1983 video, Stephen Stubbs takes American Music Show hosts James Bond and Potsy Duncan on a deadpan tour of the now long-gone gay cruising trails at the north end of Piedmont Park.

Andy Ditzler
Media 1 title: Tour of Gay Cruising Area at Atlanta's Piedmont Park in 1983
Media: Tour of Gay Cruising Area at Atlanta's Piedmont Park in 1983

Name: Plaza Theatre
Description:
Before there was lalapalooza, there was Colonel Lonnie Fain's Plazafest, in front of the Plaza Theater on Ponce in Atlanta. It featured the top local bands that Colonel Fain respected that year (1986), like Slim Chance and Now Explosion.

Dick Richards
Media:
Slim Chance in concert at the Plazafest - in front of the Plaza Theater on Ponce in Atlanta in 1986

Elouise Montague with Slim Chance at Plazafest in front of The Plaza Theater in 1986

Now Explosion 2.0 at Plazafest in front of the Plaza Theater on Ponce in 1986

Name: City Hall
Description:
For Christmas in 1982, James Bond got us VIP passes into the inner sanctum at Atlanta's City Hall where we videotaped City Council people Robb Pitts, John Lewis, Jim Maddox, Carolyn Long Banks, the distinguished Mayor of Atlanta, Andrew Young, and got to pretend we were the mayor's replacements when he's out of the office. It's hard to imagine a casual atmosphere like this anymore.

Dick Richards
Media: Goofing around in the mayor's office in Atlanta City Hall in 1983

Name: Atlanta Airport
Description:
The American Music Show's Mobile-Insta-Cam follows Wanda Peek into the Hartsfield Atlanta to meet the Eastern Airlines flight bringing Randy Barbato, The Pop Tarts, to Atlanta for a concert at Club Rio.

Three striking photographs taken on the set of The American Music Show were presented by photographer Paula Gately Tillman in a traveling exhibition that resided in the atrium of Hartsfield Airport for a month during the summer of 1997.

Dick Richards
Media:
Wanda Peek at Hartsfield Atlanta Airport Welcoming The Pop Tarts

The American Music Show On Display at Hartsfield Airport in Atlanta in 1997

Implosion of the Hartsfield Atlanta Airport Terminal 1983

Name: Variety Playhouse
Description:
Jarboe of the indy rock Swans had a special affinity for teen superstar DeAundra Peek and invited DeAundra - along with Duffy Odum, her sidekick - to come see her at the Variety Playhouse. Mister Richardson videotaped their encounter.

Dick Richards
Media: Jarboe of The Swans with DeAundra Peek at the Variety Playhouse in Atlanta in 1997

Name: Uptown Lounge
Description:
Now Explosion (after a painful breakup) reformed with an exquisite lineup that included Fireball, Lahoma van Zandt, and the House Fairy. Larry Tee composed the song "She Devil" that Now Explosion performed that night.

Dick Richards
Media: Now Explosion version 2.0 at the Uptown Lounge in Athens: "She Devil"

Name: The Chamber
Description:
SugarBaby was very nervous when she performed this night with her collaborator Paul 2000 in an act called Glam Implosion at The Chamber in Atlanta. Mister Richardson recorded her performance and her interview afterwards using The American Music Show's Mobile InstaCam.

Dick Richards
Media: SugarBaby's Show at The Chamber in Atlanta with a backstage interview

Name: Deacon Burton's
Description:
This acid trip was created for the public access television show "Dance-O-Rama" and was video taped outside Deacon Burton's legendary fried chicken restaurant in the Inman Park section of Atlanta.

Deacon Burton served delicious fried chicken in an atmosphere of Christian love. A totally unique experience that will never be duplicated.

Dick Richards
Media:
Outside Deacon Burton's Fried Chicken Restaurant in 1980s Atlanta

Eating at Deacon Burton's in 1986

Name: Nations Bank Tower
Description:
Somehow the mobile-insta-cam of The American Music Show got into this wonderful party on the tiptop of the NationsBank Building in Atlanta at North Avenue and Peachtree Street (renamed the Bank of American Plaza after the 2008 financial crash). Journalist Pam Perry provided the delightful reportage.

Dick Richards
Media: Party on the Top of NationsBank Tower in Atlanta before it became Bank of America Plaza

Name: Little 5 Points Pub
Description:
Opal Foxx made this one-time appearance with Blow Up The Tractor just before Blow Up the Tractor disappeared from the face of the earth. As seen on The American Music Show.

Dick Richards
Media: Opal Foxx (Benjamin Smoke) with Blow up The Tractor at the Little 5 Points Pub

Name: Cumming
Description:
Lahoma and Lizette were just back from Cumming GA where a Ku Klux Klan rally with the horrible JB Stoner had taken place. As broadcast on The American Music Show Atlanta

On a cold January morning in Georgia, RuPaul marches for justice in a small Southern town encountering hostile rednecks and friendly Guardian Angels including Lisa Sliwa

Dick Richards
Media:
Drag Queens at a KKK Rally in Cumming GA

RuPaul & Wanda Peek March Against the KKK in Cumming GA

Name: The Strand
Description:
Before they became world-famous as the opening act for RuPaul, The Singing Sisters played in shabby bars around Georgia performing production numbers from Broadway shows. This video captured The Singing Peeks' elaborate dance routine to "I'm Gonna Wash That Many Right Out of My Hair" from South Pacific

Dick Richards
Media: The Singing Peek Sisters "Broadway Revue" at The Strand in Marietta

Name: South Fulton County
Description:
Atlanta's southern suburbs are the topic of this humorous tour of South Fulton County conducted by a drag queen. Don Finney is the drag queen in this video produced by Mister Richardson for Ted Rubenstein's Mysteries of the Universe TV show.

Dick Richards
Media: Tour of South Fulton County Georgia Conducted By a Drag Queen

Name: Basement of Julia Bond (first filming location of TAMS)
Description:
The first few years of The American Music Show were taped in the basement of the home of Mrs. Julia Bond, mother of Julian Bond and TAMS co-founder James Bond. In the first year of the show, James was serving on Atlanta's City Council, and had been instrumental in establishing public access cable television in the city. Julian kept an office down the hall from the basement room, and occasionally popped in for an appearance. Mrs. Bond appears in this clip taped in her home for the 1981 Christmas special. Holiday safety tips are provided by Marilyn Singsyme (Molli Worthington) of the Fulton County Cooperative Extension Service.

Andy Ditzler
Location: West End: Westview Drive near Morehouse and Spelman
Media: Holiday Safety Tips for Mrs. Bond by the County Extension Agent

Name: Home of Dick Richards (2nd filming locations of TAMS)
Description:
After James Bond left The American Music Show in the mid-1980s, production moved to the Candler Park home of co-founder Dick Richards, also known as the headquarters of Funtone USA (the recording label on which Richards released LPs by RuPaul, Cocktail Girlz, Now Explosion, and the Pop Tarts). Unlike virtually all other public access television in Atlanta (which was taped in professional studios provided by the cable company), American Music Show episodes were taped at home, allowing for improvisatory freedom and levels of performance inhibited in more professional settings. This video documents the taping of the notorious 1985 New Coke Taste Test episode. Although the video satirizes the "making-of" documentary style and includes an ironic voiceover (provided by Molli Worthington), it nonetheless provides a valuable glimpse into the working methods of Dick Richards and crew, and gives a spatial sense of the taping environs.

Andy Ditzler
Location: Candler Park: Adolphus St between Nelms and Arizona
Media: The Official Documentary of "The American Music Show"

Name: Third main filming location of TAMS
